column3: @laanwj is this acceptable for the 0.12 release cycle?\n
Unless it fixes a critical bug, no. This will be reviewed and merged for 0.13.\n

Do I understand this correctly: this only make sense if you use the GUI (CoinControl enabled) and `fundrawtransaction` (over RPC with the -server option or over the GUI console)?

Although looking at this PR from an angle where CCoinControl is a core-class (not tied to the GUI) I think this would make sense.

What real-world use cases would solve this?
@jonasschnelli this is only an enhancement of the `CWallet::FundTransaction` implementation.\n

@promag: yes. I saw that this only affects fundrawtransaction. But IIRC, CoinControl can only be used over the GUI. So does that mean, that this change only affects users who uses the GUI together with fundrawtransaction (console/RPC)?\nWhat usecases would be possible with this change?\n
@jonasschnelli maybe CCoinControl should be considered core/wallet and not gui?\n
@promag: but there is no functionality/possibility to use CoinControl in core/wallet (non gui)?\n
Maybe I'm not understanding what you're saying. I'm just saying `fundrawtransaction` is a wallet RPC command and it uses CCoinControl.\n
@promag: needs a (force)push for a travis re-trigger.\n

Is the old and new code equivalent here? 
To me it looks like `coinControl.IsSelected` and the old code check for different things: IsSelected checks `coincontrol.setSelected`, whereas the old code just looks at `wtx` and `tx`.
Can you explain?

Yes they are. The only difference is that the old code performs a linear search and reimplements the `COutPoint::operator==` inline.

`coinControl.setSelected` is filled with the current inputs, which are the ones to search when the inputs are added, otherwise the same input would be duplicated.
Thanks for the explanation, makes sense to me. I missed the part where setSelected was prepopulated.\n
